sections.title: What LXMF Does
sections.content:
LXMF is the messaging protocol for Reticulum. Think encrypted email that works over any transport—internet, LoRa, HF radio, or sneakernet.

Key Features

  • End-to-end encrypted - Only recipient can read
  • Store-and-forward - Messages wait on propagation nodes for offline recipients
  • Any transport - Same protocol over 300 bps radio or gigabit fiber
  • No accounts - Your address is your public key hash

Wire Format (from official LXMF repo)

Total overhead: 111 bytes

  • 16 bytes - destination hash
  • 16 bytes - source hash
  • 64 bytes - Ed25519 signature
  • 15 bytes - msgpack header

LXMF powers NomadNet conversations, Sideband messaging, MeshChat, and custom applications like LXMFMonero.

sections.title: Sending Messages
sections.content:
Using NomadNet

  1. Go to Conversations tab
  2. Press n for new conversation
  3. Enter recipient's 32-character destination hash
  4. Type and send

Using Sideband

Sideband is the GUI client. Available for Android, Linux, macOS, Windows.

# Install on Linux/macOS (use pipx or venv)
pipx install sbapp

Android: Download APK from GitHub releases.

Using CLI

# Install LXMF tools
pipx install lxmf

sections.title: Receiving Messages Offline
sections.content:
Propagation nodes store messages for recipients who aren't currently online. Configure one to receive messages while disconnected.

In NomadNet

Edit ~/.nomadnetwork/config:

[propagation]
  propagation_node = a21f547bc1f70043a28c4e2d5b04e570

In Sideband

Settings → LXMF → Add propagation node: a21f547bc1f70043a28c4e2d5b04e570

How It Works

  1. Sender's message goes to propagation node
  2. Node stores encrypted message
  3. When you connect, your client retrieves waiting messages
  4. Messages are deleted from node after delivery

The LFM propagation node: a21f547bc1f70043a28c4e2d5b04e570

sections.title: Delivery Methods
sections.content:
LXMF offers three delivery strategies:

Direct

Creates link directly to recipient. Immediate delivery confirmation.

  • Best for: Recipient is online and reachable
  • Pro: Fast, confirmed delivery
  • Con: Fails if recipient is offline

Propagated

Routes through propagation nodes. Store-and-forward.

  • Best for: Recipient may be offline
  • Pro: Works asynchronously
  • Con: Requires propagation node infrastructure

Opportunistic

Single packet, no link establishment. Fire and forget.

  • Best for: Very short messages, broadcast
  • Pro: Fastest for small data
  • Con: No delivery confirmation

sections.title: Message Size Reality
sections.content:
LXMF handles messages of any size, but size affects delivery:

SizeBehavior
< 300 bytesSingle packet, fast
300 bytes - 10 KBAutomatic chunking, reliable
> 10 KBResource transfer, may timeout on slow links

LXMFMonero Tested Sizes

PayloadSizeStatus
Balance response~500 bytesFast
Unsigned transaction6-7 KBWorks
Signed transaction12-13 KBWorks (verified on mainnet)
Practical Limit: Keep messages under 10 KB for reliable delivery over slow links. Text messages are fine. Large files—use rncp instead.

sections.title: LXMF Clients
sections.content:
Sideband v1.8.2 (Recommended for Mobile)

Full-featured GUI client with maps, file sharing, voice calls, and telemetry.

  • Android, Linux, macOS, Windows, Raspberry Pi
  • RNode Bluetooth support
  • Offline maps for location sharing
  • 20+ built-in sensor types for telemetry
  • Audio messages via Codec2/Opus (works over LoRa)
# Desktop (use pipx or venv)
pipx install sbapp

# Android: Download APK from GitHub

NomadNet v0.9.1

Terminal-based. Messaging plus page browsing.

pipx install nomadnet

MeshChat v2.3.0

Web-based interface by Liam Cottle. Browser connects to local Python backend.

  • Windows, macOS, Linux, Docker, Raspberry Pi
  • Compatible with Sideband and NomadNet
  • Audio calls (beta) via codec2
# Docker
docker run liamcottle/reticulum-meshchat

Custom Applications

LXMF has a Python API for building your own tools. See the LXMFMonero project for a working example of custom LXMF messaging.

sections.title: LXMFMonero (Verified)
sections.content:
We built LXMFMonero to prove LXMF can handle real financial transactions over mesh networks. This is not theoretical—these are confirmed mainnet transactions.

What It Does

Sends Monero wallet operations (balance checks, transactions) over LXMF. Your spend key never leaves your device—cold signing workflow.

Architecture

Cold Client          LXMF Messages           Hub
(spend key)    ←───────────────────→    (view-only wallet)
                  any transport              ↓
                                          monerod

Verified Mainnet Transactions

TransportTX Hash (full)Time
TCP Testnet8f0295261a2ec04c6d4dcf0c9cc6b30278ab50caf9f6d27a61b562e6f3ebd761~20 sec
I2Pa793ff7bd6a0a4b168f72726e2027d283cc5fed0c8c3b1cd6693c6ef7a6fa8ee~35 sec

Verify these hashes at xmrchain.net. Both confirmed on Monero mainnet.

Message Sizes (Tested)

Payload TypeSizeNotes
Balance request~100 bytesFast on any transport
Balance response~500 bytesSingle packet
Unsigned transaction6-7 KBRequires chunking
Signed transaction12-13 KBLXMF handles reliably

Proven: Financial-grade transactions work over mesh networks. LXMF handles the complexity.

sections.title: Security Model
sections.content:
What LXMF Protects

  • Content: End-to-end encrypted. Only recipient can read.
  • Forward secrecy: Each link uses ephemeral keys.
  • Integrity: Messages are signed by sender.

What LXMF Does NOT Protect

  • Metadata: Propagation nodes see source and destination hashes
  • Timing: When you send/receive is observable
  • Location: RF transmissions can be direction-found

For Additional Anonymity

  • Route through I2P interface
  • Use from locations not associated with you
  • Don't reuse identities across contexts
